explanation: The report is not correct. The line (void)tag; is the conventional, deliberate way to mark a parameter as intentionally unused to suppress compiler warnings. MISRA C’s Rule 2.2 targets truly dead code — operations whose execution has no effect and whose removal would not affect program behaviour. The cast-to-void idiom documents intent and can affect compilation (warnings) and, in embedded contexts, can even affect timing/behaviour in subtle ways, so it is not treated as a prohibited dead-code construct. In practice MISRA checking tools treat this idiom (or an equivalent UNUSED macro) as an acceptable way to handle unused parameters rather than flagging it under Rule 2.2. Therefore the claim of a Rule 2.2 violation is incorrect.
